name: Area of the unique primitive Pythagorean triple (a,b,c) such that (a-b+c)/2 = A000045(n) and its long leg and hypotenuse are consecutive natural numbers.
reference: Miguel Ángel Pérez García-Ortega, José Manuel Sánchez Muñoz and José Miguel Blanco Casado, El Libro de las Ternas Pitagóricas, Preprint 2025.
link: Miguel-Ángel Pérez García-Ortega, El Libro de las Ternas Pitagóricas
example: For n=4, the short leg is A382843(2,1) = 3 and the long leg is A382843(2,2) = 4  so the area is then a(4) = (3 * 4)/2 = 6.
author: _Miguel-Ángel Pérez García-Ortega_, Apr 06 2025

name: Table read by rows: row n is the unique primitive Pythagorean triple (a,b,c) such that (a-b+c)/2 = A000045(n) and its long leg and hypotenuse are consecutive natural numbers.
comment: Row n=1, n=2 and n=3 are included by convention and corresponds to the Pythagorean triple (-1)^2 + 0^2 = 1^2, 1^2 + 0^2 = 1^2 and 1^2 + 0^2 = 1^2.
reference: Miguel Ángel Pérez García-Ortega, José Manuel Sánchez Muñoz and José Miguel Blanco Casado, El Libro de las Ternas Pitagóricas, Preprint 2025.
link: Miguel-Ángel Pérez García-Ortega, El Libro de las Ternas Pitagóricas
xref: Cf. A000045, A382844 (area), A382845 (sum of the legs), A095122 (semiperimeter), A001595 (short leg).
author: _Miguel-Ángel Pérez García-Ortega_, Apr 06 2025

name: Sum of the legs of the unique primitive Pythagorean triple (a,b,c) such that (a-b+c)/2 = A000045(n) and its long leg and hypotenuse are consecutive natural numbers.
reference: Miguel Ángel Pérez García-Ortega, José Manuel Sánchez Muñoz and José Miguel Blanco Casado, El Libro de las Ternas Pitagóricas, Preprint 2025.
link: Miguel-Ángel Pérez García-Ortega, El Libro de las Ternas Pitagóricas
example: For n=4, the short leg is A382843(2,1) = 3 and the long leg is A382843(2,2) = 4  so the sum of the legs is then a(4) = 3 + 4 = 7.
author: _Miguel-Ángel Pérez García-Ortega_, Apr 06 2025
